At the Nation's Table: Philadelphia;Our Lady Of the Snows
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Last week, when Philadelphia was being smothered in 30-plus inches of snow, Michel Notredame, the owner of Cuvee Notredame, a cozy European bistro, decided  it was his civic duty to keep his business open. 

     Cuvee Notredame was barely weeks old when the blizzard hit. Mr. Notredame, an engaging and jovial host, camped out in front of the fireplace at the restaurant, arranging clean bundles of linens into a bed.

One First Lady to Another
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Until recently, Eleanor Roosevelt was unrivaled as the most criticized, ridiculed and reviled First Lady. Every speech, every step and every new hairstyle was held up for scrutiny and judgment. Every penny she made was counted and condemned. 

     No wonder Hillary Rodham Clinton once said she tries to hear Mrs. Roosevelt's voice when she needs advice.

nytimes_articles.abstract:

     I was a professional cook; the experience of cooking thousands of meals for tens of thousands of people had actually convinced me I could make delicious food and rise to any culinary challenge. And a 4-year-old was telling me I was no good?

AMERICAN TOPICS : Short Takes
At the Nation's Table: Terlingua, Tex.;Dinner Out, In the Desert
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In remote Terlingua, Tex., in the mountainous Chihuahuan desert near the Mexican border, where basic amenities like indoor plumbing are not taken lightly, dinner matters. That's why "What's tonight's special?" usually refers to the Starlight Theater among the mix of locals, Rio Grande rafters and the on-location film crews who frequent this restaurant that was once a movie theater. 

     Five years ago, Angie Dean, then an eight-year resident of Terlingua, and Rob Dean, then her husband and partner, rehabilitated the dilapidated and roofless Chisos Theater, an adobe relic of this ghost town's heyday as a cinnabar mining  town in the 1920's and 30's.

wiki_events.headline: The Czech Republic applies for membership in the European Union.

pages.title: Czech Republic
pages.abstract: The Czech Republic, also known as Czechia and historically known as Bohemia, is a landlocked country in Central Europe. The country is bordered by Austria to the south, Germany to the west, Poland to the northeast, and Slovakia to the southeast. The Czech Republic has a hilly landscape that covers an area of 78,871 square kilometers (30,452 sq mi) with a mostly temperate continental and oceanic climate. The capital and largest city is Prague; other major cities and urban areas include Brno, Ostrava, Plzeň and Liberec.

pages.title: European Union
pages.abstract: The European Union (EU) is a supranational political and economic union of 27 member states that are located primarily in Europe. The Union has a total area of 4,233,255 km2 (1,634,469 sq mi) and an estimated population of more than 450 million as of 2025. The EU is often described as a sui generis political entity combining characteristics of both a federation and a confederation.

When Victims Need to Know
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In response to the story of Colete Lopez, the 6-year-old assaulted by a hypodermic needle, Gov. George Pataki has proposed legislation that would give judges the authority to require H.I.V. testing for people charged with a range of crimes, from violent felonies to disorderly conduct. 

     This idea has rekindled a debate that has existed since the H.I.V. test was developed a decade ago: Should victims of violent assault, especially rape, be allowed to know the H.I.V. status of their alleged assailants?

A Video System Shakes the Walls
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REST easy. There is no need to rush out to buy a completely new home-entertainment system. But later this year, the "next VCR" will be introduced and more room will be needed for another component (it's worth it). That was the news from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this month. 

     The digital video disk, which will be introduced in September, has the potential to improve the way people watch movies and work with computers. And with $62 billion worth of televisions, stereos, telephones and computers purchased by gadget-hungry consumers last year, according to the Electronic Industries Association, it was no wonder that many of the 93,000 visitors to the show lined up to see the digital video disk in action.

A Video System Shakes the Walls
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REST easy. There is no need to rush out to buy a completely new home-entertainment system. But later this year, the "next VCR" will be introduced and more room will be needed for another component (it's worth it). That was the news from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this month. 

     The digital video disk, which will be introduced in September, has the potential to improve the way people watch movies and work with computers. And with $62 billion worth of televisions, stereos, telephones and computers purchased by gadget-hungry consumers last year, according to the Electronic Industries Association, it was no wonder that many of the 93,000 visitors to the show lined up to see the digital video disk in action.

When Victims Need to Know
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In response to the story of Colete Lopez, the 6-year-old assaulted by a hypodermic needle, Gov. George Pataki has proposed legislation that would give judges the authority to require H.I.V. testing for people charged with a range of crimes, from violent felonies to disorderly conduct. 

     This idea has rekindled a debate that has existed since the H.I.V. test was developed a decade ago: Should victims of violent assault, especially rape, be allowed to know the H.I.V. status of their alleged assailants?

wiki_events.headline: The barge North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island.

pages.title: North Cape oil spill
pages.description: 1996 oil spill in the United States
pages.abstract: The North Cape oil spill took place on January 19, 1996, when the tank barge North Cape and the tug Scandia grounded on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island, after the tug caught fire in its engine room during a winter storm. An estimated 828,000 US gallons (3,130 m3) of home heating oil was spilled. Oil spread throughout a large area of Block Island Sound, including Trustom Pond National Wildlife Refuge, resulting in the closure of a 250-square-mile (650 km2) area of the sound for fishing.

pages.title: South Kingstown, Rhode Island
pages.description: Town in Rhode Island, United States
pages.abstract: South Kingstown is a town in, and the county seat of, Washington County, Rhode Island, United States. The population was 31,931 at the 2020 census. South Kingstown is the second largest town in Rhode Island by total geographic area, behind New Shoreham, and the third largest town in Rhode Island by geographic land area, behind Exeter and Coventry.
